sub_concepts.name: Client-Server Architecture
sub_concepts.definition: A design pattern where a client and server communicate over a network to provide services or resources.

sub_concepts.name: Peer-to-Peer Networking
sub_concepts.definition: A decentralized networking model where equal peers communicate directly with each other without a central server.

sub_concepts.name: Distributed File Systems
sub_concepts.definition: A way of organizing and storing large amounts of data across multiple machines to improve performance and reliability.

sub_concepts.name: Distributed Databases
sub_concepts.definition: A database system that spreads data across multiple servers to increase scalability and availability.

sub_concepts.name: Message Queueing
sub_concepts.definition: A method of communication between processes or systems where messages are queued up for processing when capacity allows.

sub_concepts.name: Load Balancing
sub_concepts.definition: Techniques used to distribute incoming traffic across multiple servers to improve responsiveness, reliability, and scalability.

sub_concepts.name: Fault Tolerance
sub_concepts.definition: Design techniques aimed at ensuring that distributed systems continue operating correctly even in the presence of failures or errors.

sub_concepts.name: Consistency Models
sub_concepts.definition: Theories and algorithms used to ensure that data is consistent across all nodes in a distributed system, despite concurrent updates and failures.
